title: John Groves (cricketer)
text:
John Miller Groves (21 July 1914 – 19 January 1996) was a cricket player and administrator who played <a href="first-class%20cricket">first-class cricket</a> for <a href="Jamaica%20cricket%20team">Jamaica</a> from 1935 to 1950.
After attending <a href="St.%20George%27s%20College%2C%20Jamaica">St. George's College</a> he worked as an accountant. He played two first-class matches as an opening batsman for Jamaica against <a href="Marylebone%20Cricket%20Club">MCC</a> in 1934-35, and one as a middle-order batsman and wicket-keeper against the touring <a href="Yorkshire%20County%20Cricket%20Club">Yorkshire team</a> in 1935-36. After the war he captained a young Jamaican team on its two-match tour of <a href="Trinidad">Trinidad</a> in 1949-50, making his highest first-class score of 38 in the second match, batting at number four. He also captained a Jamaica Colts side against <a href="British%20Guiana%20cricket%20team">British Guiana</a> in a five-day non-first-class match in 1956-57.
He later served as Secretary to the <a href="West%20Indies%20Cricket%20Board">West Indies Cricket Board of Control</a>. He also represented Jamaica at <a href="Association%20football">football</a> and was a football referee.
Groves was a <a href="Roman%20Catholic">Roman Catholic</a>. He married Irma Maxwell in 1940, and they had a son and a daughter. He died in <a href="Langley%2C%20British%20Columbia%20%28city%29">Langley, British Columbia</a>, Canada, in 1996.
